The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Reaching advantage position in a competitin puts me in what position as compared to others? Choices:  A: determination B: upper hand C: superior D: higher position E: skill<n>Output:		 The highest position is >5 steps above the lowest and I was closer to level A, but less effective than the other 4. B and C were not applicable<n>In the current context, upper hand was the best choice as it indicated a better position compared to others.<n><n>Input: A professor wants to create a competition where contestants produce two new inventions that have no direct effect on existing companies. The first invention has to be developed within the same year and its invention is only allowed if the second invention is the result of a year prior. Which competition would be more appropriate:  A: I, Robot B: I, Robot C: I, Robot D: I, Robot E: I, Robot<n>Output: A was the best choice as B and C were not appropriate choices which indicates that A had the upper hand. I, Robot was the only choice due to D and E being too similar to each other and C being redundant.<n><n>Input:A computer program that produces 3 images at once is being researched by a computer shop in the US as a tool for teaching computer programming. The program produces the 3 images by combining several algorithms. Which program is better for this program?<n>Output: C and D were not appropriate choices as D was not required or desirable while C was useful in theory but irrelevant in practice.<n>In this context, A was the best choice because it was the only tool available.<n>Output: The program selected was C because it is best at generating 3 images at once.<n><n>Example:<n>1 month.<n>2 months.<n>3 months.<n>4 months.<n><n>Input:You are looking for a job. You can tell if someone is good at interviewing because their responses and the way they talk are very good. Find the following jobs:<n>A manager who interviews well:<n>A manager who doesn't interview well:<n>A manager that interviews better:<n>A manager who isn't the best:<n>A manager that isn't a bad person:<n>A manager you'd want as a boss:<n>A manager that you wouldn't want your boss to be:<n>A candidate that you've known for a long time:<n>A candidate that doesn't seem too good at the interview:<n>A successful candidate that seems to be good at the job:<n>The only bad interview questions you could ask:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:where do you store wine? Choices:  A: attic B: basement C: art show D: church E: bar<n>Output:		<n>where did you store wine<n>where do you store wine<n>where did you store.<n>where do you store.<n>where did you store<n>where did.<n>where did you.<n>where.<n>where did you<n>where did you store...<n>Where did you store them?<n>Where did you store...<n><n>Input: where did you store wine? Chooses; A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H<n>Output:<n>where does you store it<n>where did you store it<n>where stored wine?<n>where store it<n>where store it on table<n>where stored it on desk?<n>Where store wine<n><n>Output:where did you store the wine?<n>where did you store the bottle<n>where stored wine? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:People always talked childlike to him, even though his disability was physical and didn't affect his what? Choices:  A: strength B: brain C: potential D: qualification E: competence<n>Output:		 He was seen as a little brat because he was so bright. He was seen as smart because he had physical limitations. He was seen as a child who was special and was even talked more childlike than his peers.<n><n>Input:Mary's parents divorced and he took her name in middle school. Her mother moved to a new house and she moved in. What would have happened under these circumstances?<n>Output: He would have moved in on his own and Mary's parents would not have gotten divorced. They would have both bought houses. How much money would that have made?<n><n>Input:Darius has 4 legs and is blind, so he relies on a balance board to walk. However, the board doesn't always stay level and falls off. His parents paid for a wheelchair which he use on rainy days and at public places. It cost them $1500. They used the wheelchair only a total of 14 times. How much time did they save?<n>Output: He saved money for the wheelchair by using it on an unusually rainy day. He saved money for the special wheel chair by not using it on the public sidewalks.<n>Since the average life expectancy of someone with blindness is 20 years old, how much time has it cost them?<n>They saved money by not using the wheelchair for rain.<n>They did not save money by not using the special wheel chair for public use.<n>They saved money by using the balance board for most of the time.<n>They did not use both tools for the same type of project.<n><n>input:A person takes $20,000 from his mother and $5,000 from his father, which is their combined current earnings. Now they need to invest $10,000 of their savings into stocks, to make a return of $35,000, plus $8,500 from other sources to account for inflation. Which of the following is the best option for their savings plan? A: stock market B. bonds C. mutual fund<n>Output: A stock market.<n><n>input:Jim and Janet have been married for 2 decades, having lived in an apartment together for 6 and having 2 kids along the way. Jim is getting old and so is Janet. If they have a child now, what should she be wearing? A: A suit for the event B: A maternity dress C: A sleep suit D: Depends on the day<n>Output: A maternity dress.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: efficiency B: getting work done C: marriage D: finishing up E: results<n>Output:		 Efficiency = <<E-E>>E = <<<<E-E>>E <<<E-E>> <<<E-E><n>Fifty percent of the marriage will be completed to complete the marriage by the end of the year, 25% will be completed by the end of the month and 25% by the end of the week.<n>Fifty percent of each engagement ceremony will be completed to complete to complete the wedding.<n>Fifty percent will be completed within each anniversary event to start of the relationship.<n>Fifty percent is enough completed to get some work done.<n>So the final equation is completed at the same time.<n>So the final results = E = <<<<E-F>>E <<<<<E-F><n>So the final result is efficiency.<n>Input: A child can spend two days at a neighbor’s house without asking permission, but one day at the neighbor’s house must ask permission before the visiting child can stay at his home. The child can only spend the entire day at his neighbor’s house for two days.<n>Output: The child cannot spend a single day at the neighbor's house before asking permission. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where would someone be likely to store a double edge razor? Choices:  A: pocket B: shower C: chemist D: drug store E: shaving kit<n>Output:		 For those options: The closest place to store an ax is the shower. Shower storage of a double edge razor is likely stored under the shower, where a shower stall will be hard to reach for and it would only take minutes to move the razor off to another spot. Shower shower storage of a double edge shaving kit will likely be stored in the bathroom. If a razor is stored in a pocket, this storage may be on a dresser, in a box, where it can be easily forgotten about.<n>Output: In the bathroom is where the most likely place for double edge razor storage is.<n><n>Input:<n>Your father wants to get a new shirt, and he has an offer: buy two shirts. Your father would need to wash and pair each shirt, and then wash each shirt twice more. Since the shirt would cost $100, your father would either need to buy an extra shirt every week, or use a different shirt. In the average adult's clothing budget, only one extra washing and matching of clothes happens every two weeks, for a total of five washing, matching and drying. Therefore, his new shirt is approximately $20 per wear, $100 times five (or 20 / 12 = 12 dollars) equals $4,240. He can spend $1000/year on clothes, and in the last ten years he could have bought $1,240 worth of clothes. Using a conservative 20 / 12 rule, that would work out to $1/year per year in excess clothes money. So if you're your father, you can spend $1100/year on clothes. You could give your dad the shirt that is missing so he has eight shirts for $400 = $400/10 = $600.<n>Output: If you can wash and matching your dad's 8 extra shirts, he would make $600. So $600 for eight shirts = $200 for 8 shirts = $600 = $600.<n><n>Input:A group of five friends plans to get new shoes, and everyone wants to get a different pair of shoes. They each purchase a pair of shoes. What amount could this group purchase for themselves?<n>Output: 5 pairs = 5 pairs of shoes<n>If everyone purchased five pairs, the total cost would be at least $350. If everyone only purchased one pair, the total cost would come out to $175.<n>Output: Each pair of shoes for 5 of the 5 people.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n>Output:		 A satisfied people are shown as the blue and red dots. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Animal farming<n><n>Input:The United States is spending $120 million a day to support troops in Lebanon, an average war cost is $500,000 per day, and Lebanon generates $3.7 billion in revenue each year from military aid and tourism. The U.S. only has one way to pay for this expenditure, through the Federal Reserve. The United States is facing a $5 trillion deficit. How will Washington solve the deficit problem?<n>Input: The money is printed by a bank and invested into treasury notes, then deposited to the Federal Reserve under the Federal Reserve Act. Borrowing money from the Federal Reserve causes a bank to produce more money, which creates even greater debt on the balance sheet of the bank. The bank buys more bonds than it sells, so as time goes on, they buy so many bonds they are buying them out of thin air. In return, the Federal Reserve gives the bank the Federal Deposit Insurance Fund, it's reserves, and its stock of banknotes. Since the Federal Reserve can't print more currency, the bank
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where would you put a computer other than a desk? Choices:  A: apartment B: table C: school D: office E: house<n>Output:		 A computer is a desk with a monitor attached to it. Software is programs that teach you things. You usually have to download it and pay for it. You might need to pay to find out how to learn some things on the computer. You must have an internet connection to get email and access online.<n>A desktop computer is larger than a personal computer. It has most of the same features. However, a desktop doesn't have the same internet connection.<n><n>Input: A man is sick of washing glasses at work and wonders why he had to do this for so many years. He decides to take the time he saved and put the money into stocks instead. He plans to retire in 10 years time. How much money does he have?<n>Output: $10000 is $10000 / ten = [10000 / 10] => $10000.00<n>So the final answer if $10000.00<n><n>Input: At a store, John asks for five pairs of socks that are the same. He asks for two pairs of socks with white labels and two pairs of socks with red labels. Once he gets all five pairs, he returns them for a refund. How did John pay for the socks without spending any money?<n>Output: So for an amount of $35, John has all 5 pairs of socks and wants to return them. He asks, "Do you want three socks or two socks?" Since John knows that for an amount of $10, he only really needs two pairs, he will either ask, "Do you want two red, two white and a striped?" Since he already has both red and white socks on hand, he will ask the clerk, "Do you have striped socks?" Once he gets 2 pairs of blue and 3 pairs of red, John pays for the other two pairs. After he pays for the three pairs, he goes down to the cashier and asks for "Five pairs white and red?" Once he gets the 5 pairs, he walks out of the store and comes back with all of the socks. Thus he paid for all 5 pairs without any sales. Since he already had all 5 pairs, there was no net spend. Thus he didn't spend any money. Thus the final answer is $0.00<n>(This is the result of subtracting an amount from an amount, dividing the resulting amount
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Long term consumption of beer can lead to all sorts of problems, it can be quite what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:The boy was too nervous to dance, so what was he doing progressively at the ball? After you have opened the door of a taxi you notice that the other friend has followed you. As you are in a hurry you open the door of the taxi but as you do so you accidentally open the door of the friend. You get out of the taxi and both of your friends are already inside. You both run after the taxi. The driver opens the door for you. As you are running after the taxi you notice that you are on the wrong side and you start to run back. The taxi driver opens the door for your friend but you don’t. You both get in the taxi and start driving. During the whole ride you stop the journey only in order to talk. When you get to your friend’s house the driver says: "He forgot his wallet". You open your wallet only to find your friends money in it. The driver says: "What money?" You open your wallet and you find a $100 bill. You don’t know what to do. You open the other wallet but you will find only $50. You open it again but you find only $20. Finally you open a third wallet and you find only $5
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:If people listen, they can understand each other better.  If they understand each other, they can do what? Choices:  A: pay bills B: swap bodies C: learn from each other D: believe in god E: talk to each other<n>Output:		 If people listen to each other, they can understand each others wants and needs. If the people they are listening to are not interested in what they are saying, they will never understand the desires of the other person. They will never learn to share, which means they will never trust each other.  They can also have arguments, which makes them not trust each other.<n>Output: If people understand each other, they will become friends and will never have arguments. All relationships are built on trust and understanding.<n>Output: People listening to each other can solve the world’s ills.<n>Output: You can listen to whoever you want to listen to.<n>Output: This is only a small part of the entire solution! See below!<n><n>Input:Two kids are sitting on a rooftop. They are talking about what they want to be when they grow up. The third child in the group, who hasn’t yet decided on a direction, says quietly, “I don’t know what I want to be.”   The other kids are curious, so she says slowly and softly, “Maybe your parents don’t know either, so it doesn’t matter what age they are.”   Her father replies, “Of course he doesn’t know what he wants to be. Who wants an old man?” The other kids laugh, but one of them tries to be sympathetic, but says sadly, “He seems to be happy being where he is now.”<n>Output: She is right. People don’t have to know what they want to be. In fact, sometimes it is better not to know. Sometimes there are people who know what they want to do, and they are successful but don’t know why. It doesn’t mean that they are failures, but it does mean that something went wrong somewhere that they didn’t know about.<n>Output: Just because someone is unhappy with the choices they’ve made, it doesn’t mean they can’t achieve everything they set out to do. There are things that will make people unhappy, but that doesn’t mean the road to happiness is impossible. They can see the positive sides of decisions they have made, and they can learn to be happy along the way.<n>Output: Children are not limited to their physical bodies—they can do anything.<n>Output: People can only do what they do
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where might a human sit for extended periods over a bowl of water? Choices:  A: bathroom B: solar system C: coffee shop D: space shuttle E: airport<n>Output:		 Use a human on water / A toilet / B / D / E to decide.<n>If we consider a person sitting for extended periods over a basin of water, then they would sit on the basin when they are in a bathroom, and then they would sit on a bath-chair when they are in the solar system or on a coffee-shop.<n><n>Input:A scientist was told that all of the water that a cow consumes, she can drink with no damage. The following is what she should do. A biologist should identify the amount of water that the cow consumes. A biologist may also determine the amount of human population that takes up that water. How should she answer this question?A: The scientist should find the number of cattle that are in the earth while being in the water that the scientist may drink.B: The scientist may estimate the amount of water that human population has taken up from earth.C: The scientist may make a statement about the amount of food used by cattle.D: The scientist may find out what amount of water that human has consumed.E: The scientist should learn a statement about the amount that humans have consumed from the earth.<n><n>Output: A biologist should identify the number of cattle that take up the water while being in the water, A biologist may calculate the amount of human population takes up that water. A biologist may learn the statement about the amount of human food consumption. A biologist may learn a statement about the human population that consumed the water.<n><n>Input:If a man and a woman are married and live in an apartment, then there must be two bedrooms, the man’s bedroom and the woman’s bedroom. What is required for the women’s room to be at least 1 meter from the man’s room?Output:To find the man’s bed and the woman’ room, you must subtract the woman’s headboard from the man’ bed.<n>A woman may sleep on the man’s sleeping platform. If the man’s headboard is located 1 meter to 1 meter from the platform, then the woman’s bed will be one meter from the man”s platform. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:If I have a forgiving attitude toward someone, what do they receive? Choices:  A: redemption B: isolation C: absolution D: great relief E: feel better<n>Output:		 They receive great relief of mind<n><n>Input:I was invited to an apple cider festival. He answers that he doesn't feel well and asks his mother to bring him home. Pablo's mother brings him home and takes him to the family room. Pablo is not in the best state and has a coughing fit. Pablo's mother asks him to put his clothes on and go to bed. Pablo does go by his room but goes into his father's room and gets a book from his drawer. Pablo does not feel very well. Pablo's father has a coughing fit. In the morning, after a few hours, he decides to take Pablo to the doctor. Dr. Gonzalez sees Pablo in the exam room. Dr. Gonzalez asks Pablo and Pablo's mother for permission. Pablo's mother reluctantly grants permission. Pablo's father gives Dr. Gonzalez his permission to treat Pablo's illness. Dr. Gonzalez gives him an inhaler. Pablo takes the inhaler and puts it in his mouth. Pablo is asleep when Dr. Gonzalez comes back to check on him. Dr. Gonzalez tells Pablo that if he keeps breathing hard, he might pass out while he's taking the medicine. Pablo's father agrees for Dr. Gonzalez to take him to the hospital. Pablo's father gives his permission to go with the doctor as well. Dr. Gonzalez tells a nurse to give Pablo one more dose of the medication before he heads home. Pablo's father tells the nurse to bring the inhaler right away. Pablo's parents drive the couple hours home. Pablo's insurance company accepts Dr. Gonzalez's permission to start the medicine so Pablo begins taking it. Pablo sees that the nurse is about to give Pablo the second dose of the medicine and tells her to instead give him the medicine. He doesn't want the medicine because he has already taken 5 in the last 15 minutes. Dr. Gonzalez tells him that the medicine will keep him alive even if he coughed. Pablo's mother tells Pablo that he doesn't need to take the medicine
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:What planet is the atlantic ocean part of? Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n>Output:		 The atlantic ocean is in B.<n>Planet A is on a plane<n>Atlas is on a plane<n>Submarine is on the ocean.<n>Atlantis is on a plane<n>Cambodia is on the ocean.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:What animal produces milk? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:What could you find at a bus station that can help you? Choices:  A: city centre B: lottery ticket C: maps D: street E: busy city<n>Output:		 City centre<n>Bus station map<n>Bus station busy city<n><n>Input:What book can you read a million times in a row? Answers: A: a million + 1 million = 2 million + 1 million = 6 million A B: million + 1 million = 1 million B C: 1 million x 10 million = 1 million x 10 million A D: 10 million x 100 billion = 1 TRILLION $1000 million = $10,000 $5000 million = $5000 $100 million = $100,000 $100,000,000,000 = 100,000 $100 billion = $100,000 trillion $1 trillion = $1 TRILLION $10 trillion = $10,000 billion $10 trillion = $1 TRIILLION $70 trillion = $70,000 $100 trillion = $100,000<n>Input:The most common number in the world is 500. What is this?<n>Output:The most common number is 500<n>Since it is the smallest negative number, 500 * 2 + 1 = 500<n>Therefore the most common number is 500.<n>Output:The most popular letter is Y<n>Since it is the least common, the amount of the word is $1 x 0.8 = $1.4 $1 x 10 million = $1 x 100 million = $1 x 1 million = $500<n><n>Input:How many people do you see playing a round of golf on Monday?<n>Output: 1.<n>What number does the same occur on a daily basis?<n>Output: 0.2 per day<n>Since it is the most common number, 0.2 * 2 + 1 = 0.2<n>Therefore the most common daily number is 0.2.<n><n>Input:On a Sunday night, a party is held at an amusement park. A man has to go to work Monday morning. What is the party?<n>Output:<n>The party is held at an arcade.<n>The amusement park is in California.<n>The party is on a second floor.<n>The man's work is 2.5 hours away.<n>The man has to stop at his apartment when he arrives.<n>The man has only to change into his work clothes.<n>The man is late because he missed the start of the party.<n>The party is 5 a.m. on a Saturday night.<n>The man is on duty at his job.<n>The party is 7 p.m. on a Friday night.<n><n>Input:What is the first day of spring?<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Rumors of roving bands of monsters killing people could lead to what? Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n>Output:		 Panic<n>So they should panic. Panic leads to mob violence, which leads to people being killed.<n>Now that they are feeling better, they should go to the library and read a book about monsters. After reading the book, they should go over the book with their friends and have a discussion about Monsters and Monsters. After their discussion, it is time to go get candy. They can go get candy or they can stay at the library and talk about Monsters and Monsters.<n>Output:<n>So the total is $1200 after the car wash $500 each at car wash $500 each after car wash $100 each after car wash $50 each after car wash $25 each after car wash<n>So the final answer $1200 minus $500 = $>>1200 <<1200/2>2<n>Now $1200 minus $500 (from car wash) is $600 so they can start getting things. The group decides to do housework since they don't have time to read a book. They are allowed to spend the money on candy and they spend a good portion of it on candy. After reading another book about monsters, they decide to go see the movie Monster’s Inc. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: roman architecture B: whitehouse C: spreadsheet D: bridge E: pantheon<n>Output:		 Write an 8*8 (5+7) grid. If you make a column with roman architecture (r/a) and line the grid with whitehouse and spreadsheet (r/a|whitehouse) it will be a pyramid. If you do the same pattern with bridge and pantheon and make a column of 4 rows and make a row with the column of columns (r/a|b) you will get a quadrilateral. If you do the pattern by letter then the result would be a 3*3*3 square pyramid.<n>Input:What would be the name of the pyramid and what is its height, width and depth? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where could you find an armchair that is used by only a few people? The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Dan outfitted his house to run on the oldest heat source on Earth. What is the oldest heat source on Earth? Choices:  A: fire B: solar energy C: sun D: house E: coal or wood<n>Output:		 (a) Fire D (a total of 12 hours of energy consumed) (b) Solar E (a total of 12.88 hours of energy required to heat the house) (c) House F (a total of 12 days of heating/cooling energy required to heat the home) (d) Coal or wood E (a total of 1.58 days of use of this heat)<n>So the final answer for each of the 10 questions is (b) Solar B D<n><n>Input: In the winter of 1821, when the temperature dropped to freezing every evening, Henry George decided to do something for warmth. He decided to build a large room with walls of brick. Each evening, he was to leave the brick walls around his room and spend a night in the space created by the brick walls. How many nights did George stay in this cold place? How many nights was he frozen?<n>Input: (a) All of them (0) (b) One night (c) None (d) Few<n>Output: One (a)<n><n>Input: A man is in a hurry. He doesn't feel like taking a bath. He takes a bath every other night. Since it is winter, and the temperature is supposed to drop, when they leave their house each night, they take their bath before heading out because of the cold weather.<n>Input: (a). There are no baths in the house (b). The two rooms have not yet had a bath (c). They will have a bath on Saturday<n>Output: (a). None (b) None of them (c) None of them (d) None of them<n>So, the final response should be the first choice.<n>In the winter of 1821 it was cold and they did not have a bath in the house<n><n>Input: When the thermometer falls below the freezing point, it is called subzero. When the temperature above zero reaches ninety degrees, it is called polar (freezing) or subzero (-1). The word polar has no words with one or two z’s in it. Therefore, what does the word polar mean? Choices: A: Cold B: Warm C: Cold (Freezing) D: Freezing (-1) So, the final answer is (-1) (a)<n>When the thermometer drops below zero, it is called sub-zero. When the temperature exceeds 90, it is called polar<n>This is the very easy one, as everyone would know the
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Why does she sing so much? Choices:  A: insane B: annoy people around C: enjoy D: inhale E: had good voice<n>Output:		 she has good voice and sings a lot to make up for having good eyes.<n><n>Input:How long does a person live for? The answers to the following multiple choices questions can not be “none of the above”.<n>Input:She lived for a lifetime B:one day B:many years B:few years C:many years D:few years<n>Output:She lived for a long long long long life. She lived for many many many many years.<n><n>Input: What is the smallest number of digits that can be represented in the number of letters in the word “four hundred”? A: 2 B:3 C:9 D:8<n>Output: Four hundred is four hundred and nine. Four hundred is four thousand nine hundred and eighty-nine. Four hundred and eighty-nine is one thousand eight-hundred and forty-nine.<n><n>Input:What is the total number of people on the plane at one time? A: 9 B:16 C:50 D:4<n>Output: There are 2987 people on the plane. There are only 508 in the hold. There are only 588 in the cockpit. There are 598 in the overhead. There are only 909 in the luggage compartment. There are 2987 on the plane. There is one in the cabin.<n><n>Input:If you have an exact amount of money, you can’t spend it because you don’t have any extra money. A: Three One Two Three B:three One Two C:one two two three D:three ones two three<n>Output: You can’t spend the whole amount. However the extra money on a card will cover the amount you didn’t spend plus 1 dollars.<n><n>Input: Which of these is the most efficient method of getting from point A to point B: A: The walk B: The plane ride C: The car ride D: The subway ride?<n>Output: The walk is the least efficient method. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Though he was an adult he still stereotypical slept on a sofa bed in his parent's what Choices:  A: garage B: horseradish C: living room D: guest room E: basement<n>Output:		 A: Yes<n>B: Yes<n>C: Yes<n>D: Yes<n>E: Yes<n>Total: Yes<n><n>Input: The man had $120,000 to invest.He invested $50,000 of it in stocks, and $50,000 in CDs (1% annual return).<n>He was in a 12% tax bracket, and was paying 8.8% of his income in taxes.<n>Then he sold his stocks and bought another set at his current cost, a fixed rate.<n>The money which he lost in the stock market should be recovered at 5%.<n>On the other hand, the income he took for taxes for the last quarter should be 7.1%, because the taxable income was $17,000.<n>He should be taxed 5.1% / $17,000 and paid the 5 % after the returns.<n>He should take the maximum allowable tax rate on $17,000.After the gains in the stock market he should be able to deduct $4,900 in this quarter.<n>After the deductions in the current quarter he should have $8,800 left.<n>So, the total investment amount is $125,480<n><n>Input:The mother of the child decided, that the child should study part time for 5 hours per week.  Output:  The parents agreed to allow the child to work five hours per week.<n>Solution:   5 hours per week = 125 hours = 5.15 hours/week = 8.15 hours/week.<n>The child is earning 8.15 hours per week<n>Therefore, his parents agreed that he can study part time for 5.15 hours per week.<n>The above output is a 5.15 hours/ week (80 hours/mth) = 4.5 hours per week = 60<n><n>Input:A man came back from a long holiday. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:The mother was worried about all the spills, so she bought a rug for under the what? Choices:  A: persia B: table C: living room D: house E: desk<n>Output:		 The mother thought buying a rug under the what would help prevent spills. The rug is $1.99 and is 50% off.<n>So the final decision is 50/60 = <<50/60=16>>16.<n><n>Input:The son was planning to read an all day book and go to dinner. Doctors told Sally there was nothing else they could do.  One day, their doctor said "We can fix this! Let's take off your meds but put these in instead" and Sally's meds were removed immediately from her body!<n>Sally's headaches felt like they were in her skull and she could not tell if they were still there.  Another doctor said that her body had gotten used to treating the headaches and would have no further side effects.  The headaches only lasted three days.  Her appetite returned as quickly as it had left it.  When the headaches seemed to go away, the headaches felt like a cold had seized them.  Doctors told her there were no side effects to that drug either.  However, Sally's headaches never went away completely.  Sally's symptoms changed every few days.<n>The headaches did not seem to bother her at first, but one night they seemed to keep her awake till dawn.  The following day she took two Benadryl and went to sleep.  This would have been better if she had taken enough to be in a daze, but she was still awake when she awoke. Her doctor told her that taking three Benadryl every night for three months would put Sally into a coma!  The second time she took Benadryl she was in complete control of her body and slept through the night.<n>Sally was taking the same medication before and after the headaches appeared and before they disappeared, and found that it helped them both.  She decided that she would continue with the medication for life so she could control the attacks and still avoid death.<n>Sally was on the same medicine before that and felt just as well with or without the headaches.  Doctors found this to be the only cause for the improvement in her health.  Their doctor said "You seem like you are just fine."<n>The doctors are not certain what caused the headaches when she started the medication in January. They now believe the headaches
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:The robot shockingly began to read book after book, it had apparently done what? In that case, the robot should learn to take its clothes off.<n>Therefore, the remaining $200 in robot money (which is $20) is used to buy one book. And I just bought one book. And the robot is now reading book, which is number 6.<n>Thus there is $20 in all of robot money, $20 + $20 divided by 6 equals $6.<n>Therefore, the robot earns $6 x 6 = $6<n>So the total amount for book 6 + $6 = $6.50<n>Which amount does the robot earn? $60.50 /.10 = $13<n>Which amount does the car cost? $1700 = $>>1900<n>We now have $19, $19 - $20 = $12<n>How much gas do the robot has used? $12 x.03 = $3.<n>Therefore, the total gas used is $6.00<n>Total gas used = $1.50<n>So what did the robot earn? $13 x $12 = $20<n>Which amount of robot money is left, $20?<n>Output: That amount of robot money is still $20<n><n>In a group of six students, each student has the choice to split the money equally among themselves. Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n>Output:		 A = "Military base" B = "fountain" C = "base" D = "bus stop" E = "cinema"<n><n>Input: If you're giving away $100 bills on Saturday, what can you do with the money when you get to the register?<n>Output: Ask people a simple question like this one:    How old are you?     Answer:      How old is $100?      Answer is $100<n>What if the person has no idea how old $100 is?  Answer:   They give you $100.<n>Does that mean they hate $100?  Answer:  NO.  They gave you $100 so you will learn something.<n>You'll learn about the amount of money the government gives to the people of other countries.  The fact that you'll use those two facts to find out the number of people on the planet is a good reason for giving this gift.  People are lazy, and they won't learn anything if they don't see the dollars.  I think it would be more satisfying to have them give you $40 instead of $100.<n>Does the question have to be worded so as to get all the right answers?  Answer:  Yes.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where may I view sharks in a clear tunnel? Choices:  A: south pacific B: sea world C: pacific ocean D: indian ocean E: gulf of mexico<n>Output:		The first choice requires knowledge of shark species and geographical location and the second one requires knowledge of each of said species as well as geography. Therefore, the first option requires knowledge of each species while the second one requires knowledge only of Geography. Therefore, the second option, that of the first one will not work. For the third choice, the sharks cannot be found even in clear tunnel. It is said that sharks are rarely seen above the ocean's surface while the third option states that the sharks are never seen above the ocean's sea surface. Therefore, the second one is not possible. In the fourth choice, sharks can be sighted almost anywhere as stated in the second one. Therefore, the fourth option is possible. Let's assume that there are four sharks in a clear tunnel. It is now stated to me that this tunnel is the Atlantic ocean. As I am about to move through the tunnel to the west, the tunnel ends and the sharks disappear. The problem is I can't see them anywhere. In the fifth and last task, the sharks can be sighted just about anywhere in the sea. Therefore, the final option is the sixth one. Let's assume that four sharks are visible near the water's surface. And the sixth option is only possible in this case. That is the sixth option where the sharks are never seen in the water but in caves hidden there. The final solution is sixth option.<n>It is written that sharks are seen near the surface of waves. The six option is found here. In the eighth task, sharks are not rare wherever in the sea they are. That is the eighth option. Finally, the ninth task is the tenth one. Sharks are not seen everywhere. That is the ninth option.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where could you find a theater which only has unpaid actors? Choices:  A: shopping mall B: hospitals C: populated area D: school E: military base<n>Output:		 All 6<n><n>input:An eight year old boy was upset at having to read about bad things in the newspaper. [0-100]<n>Output: 100 [0-100] = 10 [0-100] and 4 [0-100]
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Why would someone confess to committing murder?
