James = 3<n>So now let's add population   It makes up about 5% of the world population<n>So we have 5% of the world's population<n><n>Input: A mother sends her son to school with a backpack. Her son walks around school after school with the backpack. She tells him to put his lunchbox on the porch and that she will come and get it later. He ignores her and goes back into the school. How many times does the mother walk around and get the backpack she left for her son?<n>Output: He never leaves school with the backpack.  After one day, he leaves it on the porch and comes back for it later.  He must have forgotten to write any homework inside.  The mother finds that the lunchbox has been there for over a week but she never returns to get it.  She asks the school if he did have homework, but no one at school had heard of him having it. Thats when she finds that the backpack was actually missing.   She tells the teacher that her son might have left it somewhere.  The teacher tells the mother that they are not going to be able to locate it but the next day the boy is asked to come back.  The mother takes the boy back to school and he goes to the teacher looking to see if he had homework. The teacher asks him if he did have homework but he hasn't turned this sheet in the morning. The teacher then explains the situation to the mother, and the teacher admits to leaving the backpack on the porch.  The mother admits that she had let her son wander into school but thought he would come home and get the lunchbox himself.  The teacher is glad that her son came back at least once and tells her how important it is to teach her son responsibility and discipline. The teacher gives her his permission to not keep a close eye on him after that day.  The mother was given his permission to let her son go wandering into school, because she knew she would never find the backpack herself.   That same day, the teacher notices the backpack has been replaced and puts it back on the porch.  She gave the permission, even knowing he would go looking for it the next day.

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:John hated mosquitoes.  It wasn't the bloodsucking that he disliked, it was that the insects made what? Choices:  A: fly B: buzz C: move D: honey E: help flowers pollenate<n>Output:		 John hates mosquitoes because they're insects that kill and are insecticides which kill

Charlie will drive the car.<n>Charlie doesn’t want to put money into the account. How would Charlie, John, and Paul be the only ones to get rich? Answers:<n>A) John drives the car all the time.<n>B) Charlie has a car problem in which he can’t drive, so John drives the entire time, but Charlie can’t drive the car, so Paul drives the whole time.<n>C) John drives the entire time.<n>D) Paul drives the entire time, and Charlie drives the car, but none of them know the other is driving the car, so they all get equally rich.<n>E) Paul drives the entire day and Charlie drives the entire day, but they don’t want to give him the car back

The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:When a monkey is taken away from their home they are often brought to this place where people wear white coats. Choices:  A: rain forest B: research laboratory C: cage D: treetops E: south africa<n>Output:		 B<n><n>Input:There is an egg in the garden with a yellow and white yolk. Someone guesses 7. How many eggs does this egg contain?<n>Output: 7 = 7 x 100 = 21<n>There are 8 eggs in the garden with a green and red yolk. Some people say 8, others say 9. How many eggs does the egg with a green and red shell contain?<n>Output: 9 = 8 x 100 = 21<n>So, it has 9 x 1/2 = 7 eggs on the shell.<n><n>Input:When two people give each other the same toy, how often will they do this?<n>Output: The sum of frequency is usually less than the sum of sum of frequency by a factor of 2, if the toy is not given to you at random it is not random. So the toys in the first and third cases usually have the same frequency but the toy in the second case is more likely.<n>Output: 4,5 = 4,4,2,4,3<n>So in the first case, the toy was very likely given to me by another person.<n><n>Input:In a group effort, the group will decide who sits in the front rows and who sits in the back rows. The group must give some people the choice of two rows or three rows so they can have the full benefit of the row they picked. The members of the group agree to do this. What is the group?<n>Output: The group is one large table.<n><n>Input:Each morning, a girl at school who sits beside a boy on a bus, is supposed to carry one piece of paper. One piece of paper which will never be seen again by them. If they see one of the other boys carrying the paper, how will the teacher know?<n>Output: One paper = 1 piece of paper x time x effort, where time= time the rest of us take to get it done.<n>So, in the morning the first person should have paper 1 in the first row, the second paper 2 in the third row, etc, the rest of us take time to get it done.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n>Output:		 (1) bathe (1) bite (1) copulate (1) D die of cancer (1) C obesity (1) B<n>John's final answer: D<n><n>Input: John is very enthusiastic about a new hobby that he gets online for free in exchange for a personal promise to post pictures in a community newspaper. He decides to ask someone for a picture of what he is about to get into, and this person decides to let him. He decides to ask for a picture of his future wife's feet. If there are three feet in every photo, does he choose her feet or the third picture, which also has three feet in it?<n>Output: (1)(1)(1)(1)<n>So the final answer was yes<n><n>Input: John has decided to move away from his family. He is planning to buy a piece of land and live in it. There are two choices for where he should live:  a) a large ranch in Nebraska or  b) a small cabin in the Midwest.<n>Output: The final answer is (b)<n><n>Input: John's neighbor has a swimming pool and so John decides to try it out one day, for a dollar. He is careful about the water level and gets in without any harm. Once he is in it, he becomes thirsty, but the water stops flowing at an arm-length away from him at just the right time. This is very strange.<n>Output: John's final answer: D
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where did the person have to walk downstairs to get the tool? How long is each player's time allotted while they are on their bases?<n>Input:The group of six men are all assigned their own bases, and for each one, they have to go to the base, pick up the ball, catch it and bring it back to the pitching side. They are each given a number until they have finished and then they are counted out. Each time they finish they earn two cents. The men have to get on their bases, and work on their bases with the other men at their own pace.<n>Input:What does how long the group of six men get to do their base running tasks after that, add the fact that one man only has to catch the ball once, and add in that one man has only to hold the ball once, and how many seconds does that add up to?<n>Output:The total of how much each man gets to do his job while on his base is:<n>Group number 6 earned 5 cents.<n>Group number 1 earned 4 cents.<n>Group number 2 earned 3 cents.<n>Group number 3 earned 2 cents.<n>Group number 4 earned 1 cents.<n>Group number 5 earned.75 cents.<n>Group number 6 earned.25 cents.<n>Group number 7 earned.05 cents.<n>Total: 7 cents.<n><n>Output:The six players were assigned different bases according to how many times they got to

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? The individual must choose one door to use for entry. Which door do you think he should choose?<n>Output: A: The back door B: The front door C: The rear door D:<n><n>Input:The car travels in circles and the speed of the car is 30 km/h. What should the person in the passenger seat do?<n>Output: What does the person in the passenger side of the seat want the driver to do?<n><n>Output:When a family is given a house in the middle of nowhere, they soon learn how to make their house a home. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:George ruined the surprise. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:If I take my heifer out East, where's a place we might end up? In any other month she can't have sex at all.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:What divider stores papers for work or school? Choices:  A: street B: binder C: obesity D: living room E: office suite<n>Output:		 Choices:  1: Street 2: binder 3: obesity 4: living room 5: office suite 6: living room

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:If someone is outgoing what are they likely to seek? Choices:  A: new experiences B: playfulness C: own house D: good looking E: beautiful<n>Output:		 They are likely to seek new experiences and being outgoing.<n><n>Input:If the first ten pages of a book costs 50 cents, a book lasting a million pages costs $500 (50 * 150 = $30) – a book lasting ten years costs $5,000 (100* 150 = $200) – and a book lasting thirty years costs $15,000 (100* 250 = $1,000) how much is the first ten pages? How much does the last fifty pages cost? How much does the first ten years and last fifty pages cost?<n>Output: The first ten pages cost 50 cents and last fifty pages cost $50 (50 x 150 = $50).<n>The first ten pages are cost 50 cents and last twenty pages are cost 250 cents each, total $60.<n>The first ten pages last ten pages cost 100 cents and last twenty pages cost 250 cents, total $50.<n>The first ten are cost fifty cents and last twenty pages last thirty dollars, total $90.<n>The first ten is cost fifty cents and last thirty pages last thirty dollars, the total total $55.<n><n>Input:In a given amount of time and with a given number of characters, what do you think people most often use Facebook for? The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:A government seeks what over it's people? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where above your kitchen sink could you store canned food? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where can you purchase food and eat it at tables? I got the answer for you.<n>You got the "answer" from my "answer" - so, there is no right or wrong and you got the correct answer. Congratulations.<n>You got the correct answer. There is no right or wrong. It is between $400 and $410. The way I worked out it I took the total from this question and divided by two and the total from this question divided by two and the net amount was $410. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. While in the hospital, the man asks doctors to help him determine the amount of damage the deer caused in his car. Doctors tell him that a deer can damage a car up to $10,000. They told him that he can't drive for two months, but then he got into an accident at 70 miles per hour. How is half of that $10,000 divided?<n>Output:<n>The deer damage is divided in half, $300 each.<n>The man is able to drive two months after the accident because he uses an at-home car wash.<n>The deer damage is not divided into halves because the deer damaged only a portion of the car.<n>It is difficult to split the deer damage, even with the doctor's help.<n>So the correct answer is 50.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:If you hit someone while driving what could happen to that person? Choices:  A: deaths B: get arrested C: moving D: using gas E: may die<n>Output:		 The worst thing that could happen is that you get arrested and/or the person dies.<n>You can also choose to hit the person with your car, but you won't be able to stop. The only person you can hit is a person you already know - not a complete stranger.<n><n>Input:A group of 30 people are at a party and they start eating. The problem is, since they don't need to go anywhere for three hours, what about each one of them?<n>Output: You can eat as much as you want if you have a stomach.<n>You can go for a walk, but you're afraid of having to walk anywhere.<n>You can call someone and order them to get you some food.<n>You can go on a walk but you're afraid someone might see you.<n>You can order some food or drink online and it will arrive at your place the next day.<n><n>Input: A friend (Joe) and you are sitting at a table of four. You both pay for one drink. You order the same food, but in separate places ($20 food). How much does your food cost?<n>output:$20/4 = <<20/4=22>>22<n>His cost comes out to be $22.50/4 = <<22.50/4=26>>26<n>Your cost comes out to be 22.50/4 = 22.50/4=30<n>So the final answer was 30<n><n>Input: A man and his wife sit at a table of 4. You order a drink ($10 drink) and then a second one ($10 drink) with her. How much does each one of you pay for the drinks ($5 drink for you two, $5 drinks for your spouse)?<n>Output: Each drink is $5 for him and $7 for her.<n>His drink is $10/20 = <<20/20=22>>22<n>Her drink is $11/20 = <<11/20=27>>27<n>So the total cost of the drinks for both you and your spouse comes out to $22/20 = >>>22-<<20/20=27>>>27.<n>So the final total was $25<n><n>Input: The two men (Alan and Steve) are traveling to a lake to fish. If there is no long-term savings program and there is no cost reduction or benefit program, the savings will be $600,000. Therefore, the federal government must fund these programs and will take in $600,000 each year. The president must pay taxes on the $600,000, but his total income could be $800,000 for one year. If there is no cost reduction, he will take home $800,000 and will be a millionaire. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where would people be looking at some things which can move, but are not moving? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where do  you park in the parking lot with shopping bags? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:James went to the best steakhouse outside of the South. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:The window of the Honda was hit from the inside, not the outside. Both are incorrect locations.<n>E. Both are incorrect locations because only bridges are inside.<n>F. None of the above.<n>G. None of the above<n><n>Input: How many stars should the total score of the movie be?<n>Output: 2 stars should be used.<n>2 and 1 stars are the most popular answers.<n>1 star is a misspelled answer suggesting that it is a movie that should have many stars.<n>100 stars are more common than 5 stars.<n><n>Input: If the score of an average player is 1 or 2, how many points should that player get?<n>Output: The average answer is a score of 1.75, which is the average score that any given person will get in a game of basketball, golf or tennis.<n><n>Input: In a poker game, your partner has a five-card hand and you have a ten and four. Do you have to play five poker cards before folding?<n>Output: The correct answer is a Yes.<n>For instance, if your hand consists of two queens + four spades, you must play five cards before drawing the next hand. Even if you are betting 100, you will end up doing no better than the average player. The only reason to fold is if your hand is worse than the others.<n><n>Input: Find the minimum number of points needed to play the lowest hand in the following match-up:<n>Output: 9 is the minimum score needed to win.<n>The card on the bottom hand needs 3 total points to win.<n><n>Input: What is the difference in ages between Jim and Jack? If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:What do customers do in a store? How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n>Output:		 Learning A $1000 A $1500 B $1000 C $1500 D $1000<n>How to find an average? First we have to find a point from which to draw our average. The average is the average of all choices. If you don’t know where to read this from, you can try this.<n><n>Input: An earthquake has occurred in Nepal, causing many deaths and injuries. Approximately two million people have become homeless. The quake occurred at night, so many people were not able to get help. People in their homes have started to go to the emergency rooms to be treated for injured or dying family members. People living outside have spent hours waiting in line for health care. Who is responsible? Who should be held responsible?<n>Output: If you would not want money from someone, what person is the best and worst person to ask for your money?<n><n>The following information is from a postcard. You are given two ways to find the average. The first player was Kevin. Kevin shot the ball into the basket, but didn't put the ball through the hole. Who played next?<n>Output: The second player, John, missed the shot and had to go for two. The other two players also missed. The last player, Chris, was trying to get a point so his team would have a chance for a comeback.<n><n>Input: A man and a woman were having an affair. Their relationship was becoming more and more important in their lives. On June 6, they were married. What is the significance of June 6?<n>Output: You should learn something about June 6, if you are having an affair. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Sam didn't like the people he met while traveling.  What might he do to get away from them? In addition, the group is divided into three teams.  Who will spend the most money during the trip?<n>Output: Three teams are left. What must the team do?<n>Output:<n>Team A wins the gift certificate.<n>Team B wins the gift certificate. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Illegitimate designer handbags will not have a certificate of what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: revealing information B: being ridiculed C: problems D: more funding E: telling all<n>Output:		 To make enough money<n>Company makes enough money from investor interest<n>Revelations of information - it will raise money from investors and could be a good investment<n>Laughter - it will give people a good laugh if the company is funny. If its really that bad, people can choose D<n>Company does not need to tell investors everything<n>There's less risk involved  Since only a small percentage of the company has to go public<n><n>Input: There are two groups of children. The first group has an average age of 17. The second group is 25. They have three classes. The first class has 50 students, the second has 175 students and the third has 250 students. The first group has 8 students a week; the second group has 40 students a week. Two students go to class every day for three days. Two students are absent for 1 day and one day is a week day. How many students would be in the first group?<n>Output: 50 students in first group. That equals 7.5% of the 50. The fifth group of 25 people has 7.5% of 50. The average of 7.5%. So the fifth group has 9.2%. So the average of 9.2% would be 100.<n>Students are absent for 1 day only. So the average of 0.5% is 3 and the average of 3.25% is 6.5% = 3%<n><n>Input: A high school student is on a study abroad trip to Rome. She is on a sightseeing tour; she is in a wheelchair. On a day she has lots of time on her hands, she can’t help but write down her thoughts. At first she only wrote down the names of the sights, but then she started to think of how her life might turn out after she finished her trip and returned home. She had only about 20 pages to write. If she finished after 20 pages, what would she say?<n>Output: Write one to two pages about what your study abroad experience was like on your current vacation. (Remember to only write down your thoughts about your vacation now. You will want a detailed report about the trip to write later)<n>So one would say he would be able to write 20 pages about his Rome visit as he could imagine where he might go on vacation in the future.<n><n>Output: A student wants to make a movie. He has lots of time, and there is no teacher present in his class. How well can he write a script?<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:How can a person end up stopping standing in  puddle? Choices:  A: move away from B: laying in C: sweating D: movement E: walking out of<n>Output:		 Stop at a spot in puddle<n><n>Input:Why do you think the doctor asked the nurse the question “Is today the last day I will work?” The doctor asked the nurse this because he didn’t want to get fired if he didn’t. So why are you asking me this? The nurse asked the doctor the question because he didn’ ask her and told her she will always be working<n>Output:Doctor said yes<n><n>Input:Pablo loves to read. When he reads, he usually finishes an hour later than usual. At the end of the day, Pablo still has a whole hour he can use to read or do some math. If he finishes his reading, he gets a prize. How much time do Pablo have left to do something he loves?<n>Output:He has about 10 minutes left<n><n>Input:In the beginning of the test, one of the children is given a word with three letters and she has to pronounce all words before completing the sentence with the number of letters she just said. The three letters each add up to nine, so she needs to say eight as well. She does so. What is the number of letters she needs to say?<n>Output:She needs to say 7.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:What eastern state is home to a mountain? Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n>Output:		 which state is home for a mountain?<n>Start by entering your answer. Write the correct answer below:<n><n>Input:A person has two sons which are 5 and 7. His wife is also present. How many sons does this father have? Output:A person has two kids with 2 wives: 1 son 7 and 1 son 5. A third wife was also present. How many children does the father have?<n><n>Output:A person has a son 14, a daughter 12, two more daughters 2 and 7, and one son 2. Another wife and father is also present. How large is the man's household?<n><n>Input:There are 60 people in a business. The work is done on a 6-hour basis, and the manager gets paid $70 per hour. At the beginning of the week, the manager buys $25 worth of bread, drinks 2 glasses of wine, and 1 slice of pizza. What is the total cost of the employees' meal? If you didn't order something, what is the total cost of yours?<n>Output: It is $60 divided by 60<n>So the total cost of everyone's meal will be $60 divided by $70/6 = ≈ $35<n>A man gives $25 to his coworker, but $500 is taken out of his paycheck to pay for the employee's meal. What is $500 divided by 2 employees?<n>Output: It will be $250 divided by 5<n>A man gives $50 to another coworker, but $250 is also taken out of his paycheck. What is $250 divided by 1 employee?<n>Output: It it will be $150 divided by 2 employees<n>A man gives his coworker $25, but $25 is also taken from his paycheck. What's left is $15 + $150 = $20<n>A man gives his co-worker $40 and $50. Where is the $25 left?<n>Output: $30 + $50 = $40<n><n>Input:The number of feet in each leg is the following: 1 10 3 1 1 0 4 7 5 1 7 5 8 3 1 8 6<n>Output:2 10 3 1 1 1 <9> 11 8 3 1 1 9> 13 1 8 6 8<n><n>Input:If someone was willing to sell $500 worth of goods, how long would it take the person to pay for their goods?<n>Output: The person would take 5 seconds to pay for their items with a $500 bill.<n><n>Input

There are two alligators in the creek. Which of the following would be an appropriate action for the alligator to do?<n>Output:<n>dip its head in the creek<n>grab an alligator's tail<n>bite its head off<n>The alligator's head will remain in the creek for a little while,<n>The alligator will be fed to the other three alligators.<n>The alligator will soon die,<n>And, it's head will be cut off and thrown into the creek.<n>None of these are good things,<n>But the worst thing is...<n>To swim between the<n>alligators, then swim to<n>the other side<n>to grab the alligator's tail<n>Then, swim the length of the creek.<n>None is good<n>Or the worst.<n>All is good.

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n>Output:		KFC = KFC<n>The question begins with "What is" the question then adds choice's with an answer. The answer choices are "A" "B" "C" "D" "E" "F" "G" or "H" "I" "J" or "K".<n>KFC = KFC(A)(C)(D)(E)(F)(G) or "H" KFC(A)(B)(C)(D)(D)(E)(G)<n>If "A" is the best answer, then there is only one correct answer. If "A" is not the best answer, then more than one correct answer is necessary and at least one person answered "B" or "C" or "D" or "F" "G".<n>Output: Start by determining the number of correct answers as needed. If more than one correct answer answers all the questions correctly then the correct answer is “B” or “C” then “Totals”<n><n>Input: What is the difference between the following two equations:<n><n>A1 = X^2 + B1<n>A1 + B = XB1<n>Where X1 and XB1 are two variables. The number 6 is also a variable. x^2 and 2 were variables in the equation that came before. Therefore, X^2 = 1 and 2 is a variable.<n>Output:<n>I (6) (3) 1 (1) 1 (3) 1 (3) I (2) 1 (1)<n>Thus:<n>I = 6 - 1<n>I = 3 + 1<n>I = 0 + 3<n>If no correct answer(s) are available, then the correct answer is "b".<n>But, if there are a correct answer(s) available, the correct answer is "A".<n>Output: Start with the correct answer. If the correct answer is "I", then the problem statement asks for a “+” before “A”. But, there were no correct answer(s). So, the answer(s) “A” are correct.<n>If the answer(s) that are wrong are “F” then:<n>Since “6” is not a variable and since “2” is not a proper number, there are 2 possible answers: “F” or “H”.<n><n>Input: Two friends
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Where does a marmoset not usually go? Choices:  A: dictionary B: wilderness C: fly D: underground E: colorado<n>Output:		 The marmoset does not live in the wilderness.<n><n>Input:If you make a cake which has the ingredients sugar and flour and baking powder what percent of the cake's ingredients are made from sugar?<n>Output:If cake has the ingredients sugar, flour and baking powder, then the cake is made from <%of cake ingredients are sugar...so 50% cake = 50% flour and baking powder%.<n>Output: If cake has the ingredients sugar and cooking spray what proportion is baking powder?<n>[edit=20 hours ago, this is a little complex. you see, if you have a cake which uses cooking spray, the other half is what is left of the sugar in the cake - hence the 50%)<n>output:If cake uses baking powder and baking sugar, how much of the cake is baking powder?<n>output:0.5% cake has baking powder = 100% remaining cake makes baking powder 50% cake = 50 of all remaining cake = 100% sugar<n><n>The cake has 4% flour, 20% sugar and 10% baking powder. What proportion of cake is cake?<n><n>Output:50% cake = 0.5 x 20% = 20% flour and baking powder = 0.5 x 10 = 10% sugar<n><n>Input: A math book is called "A Real Algebra Book" because it can be used to practice the multiplication tables. One of the multiplication tables found in the book uses the term "square root" to express the multiplication rule. For instance, 7: 5 is the square root, 3: 5 is the square of the result. Is there another way to use the term square root other than the square root formula to express the multiplication rule?<n>Output: Yes, you can replace the term "square root", by "totals". The square root and the total are one and the same thing.<n><n>Input:A cake contains the following ingredients:1.7 pounds flour2.7 pounds sugar3.25 ounces butter4.95 ounces milk5.4 ounces buttercream6.1 ounces chocolate7.1 ounces butter<n>Output:100 cake = 200 cake<n><n>Input:An eight-year-old boy and his mother have an argument about which Christmas presents she should buy him. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input:Three quarters of what are covered by the ocean? Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n>Output:		  A: water falls A: beach B: river C: beach D: river<n><n>Input: A house is a great building made of wood.
